messages: 2cdd7064b290132617248dbfd85f740e (17:51): 1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb you mentioned (w.r.t to my query on legend elm's content model) < "Content model" describes what the element is allowed to *contain*.

2cdd7064b290132617248dbfd85f740e (17:51): "Categories" describe what the element *is*. ¬†(And then "Context"...describes where it can be used.) > Am I right in assuming HTML4 did not explicitly declare category/context and only HTML5 does so?
1f8387eb43f131d7c309a90a4e36b5cb (17:52): 2cdd7064b290132617248dbfd85f740e: I'd have to check HTML4 to be sure.  Been a while since I've read it.
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (17:52): It declared context, surely
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (17:52): Isn't that what the DTD is all about?

2cdd7064b290132617248dbfd85f740e (17:53): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9  e.g. http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-html40/struct/global.html#h-7.5.1 for Body element there is explicit content model associated (%block; | SCRIPT)+ +(INS | DEL)
2cdd7064b290132617248dbfd85f740e (17:54): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 Nothing explicit about context.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:54): The "%block" definitions are sort of about context
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:55): but in general the child->parent relationships aren't explicit, you have to derive them from te parent->child data in the DTD
2cdd7064b290132617248dbfd85f740e (17:55): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c %block defines what can go WITHIN body element and not what content model the element ITSELF is.

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:56): 2cdd7064b290132617248dbfd85f740e: But some other part of the DTD says that <div> etc *is* a %block, i.e. saying it can be used in all contexts that accept blocks
2cdd7064b290132617248dbfd85f740e (17:57): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c is there a ref here: http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-html40/sgml/dtd.html
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:58): <!ENTITY % block "P | %heading; | %list; | %preformatted; | DL | DIV | NOSCRIPT | BLOCKQUOTE | FORM | HR | TABLE | FIELDSET | ADDRESS">
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:59): That's kind of the explicit declaration of category
2cdd7064b290132617248dbfd85f740e (18:00): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c so any element in that list has a category of Block?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:01): Yes, and can be used in any element whose content model includes "%block;"
2cdd7064b290132617248dbfd85f740e (18:02): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c ah k. but contexts are not specified though I think. They are assumed. E.g. ins and del.
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:03): 2cdd7064b290132617248dbfd85f740e: (this is not twitter, no need for the @ sign)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:07): apparently just bought some "Nytol 0-A-Night" if you believe the recepit
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:08): That doesn't seem very good product design, if you're expected to take none a night
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:08): They'll never get any repeat customers
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:08): Maybe you take it during the day
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (18:08): That doesn't stop homeopathy
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:09): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: That's not how homeopathy works - you have to keep buying their expensive water regularly
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:09): so they've got the right idea
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (18:10): You could just use half, and then refill yourself
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:10): Hopefully I can finally get off a 3am-10am sleep pattern :\
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:10): Being ill and ending up with that sort of sleep pattern scuks
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:10): *sucks
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (18:10): At least you have the excuse of being ill
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:11): It was so sad, I missed going to Oslo.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:11): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: You could move to a timezone several hours westwards, and then your pattern would be fine
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:12): I tried to do that, but the clocks changed too.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:12): So I'm still in the same timezone, despite moving west.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:12): Go west more
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (18:12): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: Get me a plane ticket.
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (18:12): Take up residence on a hot-air balloon
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:13): Build an underground city
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (18:15): I don't have a problem being awake at night, it's just that other people insist on only being available during working hours
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:18): It's strange that everyone has roughly the same working hours

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:18): It means you're busy working while everyone else is available, and as soon as you stop working and have some free time everybody else stops working and becomes unavailable
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:19): It'd be more efficient if everybody was assigned a random number between 0 and 24 at birth, which is the offset applied to all their working hours
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (18:20): because then a large fraction of people would be available at all times, and you'd never have to worry that all the shops are about to shut
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (18:24): Well, it's sort of annoying if your business hours don't overlap with people you're supposed to interact with
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (18:24): (E.g. anyone who's ever been on a team with more than six hours time zone difference)
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:24): In Sweden the shops almost all shut for much of the weekend
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:25): typical opening hours might be 11-15 on Sat. only
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:26): There are literally would-be shoppers listlessly wandering the steets looking for places to spend money
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (18:26): This pretty much disproves economics
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (18:27): There are social arguments for having non-business hours
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (18:27): So the economists might just be repressed and unable to optimize
40cddb5ac261f4694179715cd8424278 (18:27): All the swedish weekend money gets spent in bars and clubs instead ^^
